title: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)
scope: ** Acute inflammatory polyradiculoneuropathy including AIDP, AMAN, AMSAN, and Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) variants. Covers acute diagnosis, respiratory monitoring, immunotherapy (IVIG/PLEX), autonomic dysfunction management, pain control, and rehabilitation planning. Excludes CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy — separate template), tick paralysis, and chronic neuropathies.

Essential/First-line.target: Nerve root enhancement (anterior roots in AIDP); exclude compressive myelopathy, spinal cord lesion, epidural abscess

Essential/First-line.timing: Ideally within 3-5 days of symptom onset (may be normal in first 48h); repeat at 2-3 weeks if initially non-diagnostic
Essential/First-line.target: Demyelinating pattern: prolonged distal latencies, conduction block, temporal dispersion, prolonged F-waves, absent H-reflex. Axonal pattern (AMAN): reduced CMAP amplitudes with normal velocities
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None significant; avoid anticoagulated patients for EMG needle exam

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day IV x 5 days (total 2 g/kg); infuse over 4-8h per dose; slow initial rate and increase per protocol. Start within 2 weeks of symptom onset for maximum benefit

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: IgA deficiency (use IgA-depleted product); acute renal failure; anaphylaxis to immunoglobulin
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Vital signs q15min during first infusion, then q30min; renal function (BUN, Cr) before and during; headache (aseptic meningitis); thrombotic events; hemolysis (haptoglobin, LDH, direct Coombs if symptoms)

dosing.instructions: 5 exchanges over 7-14 days (typically every other day); each exchange 1-1.5 plasma volumes; use albumin replacement. Start within 4 weeks of symptom onset

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hemodynamic instability, severe sepsis, active bleeding, heparin allergy (for circuit anticoagulation), poor vascular access
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP and HR continuous during exchange; calcium (citrate toxicity: tingling, cramping); fibrinogen; CBC; electrolytes; line site infection

dosing.instructions: Indications (20/30/40 rule): FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF weaker than -30 cmH2O, >30% decline in FVC from baseline, or clinical respiratory distress. Use non-depolarizing agents (avoid succinylcholine — hyperkalemia risk). RSI with rocuronium preferred

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Ventilator settings per ICU protocol; sedation; daily spontaneous breathing trial when improving

Referrals & Consults.indication: All suspected GBS; diagnostic confirmation, treatment initiation
Declining respiratory function; intubation decision; ventilator management
Early passive ROM to prevent contractures; gradual mobilization as tolerated; gait training
Upper extremity function, ADLs, adaptive equipment
Rehabilitation planning; disposition (inpatient rehab vs SNF)
Discharge planning, family support, financial resources
Anxiety, depression, PTSD (common in ICU patients)
Bedside spirometry (FVC, NIF); pulmonary toilet; ventilator weaning
Enteral feeding plan if intubated; caloric needs during recovery
If triggering infection unclear or atypical presentation

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED / Call 911 if: increasing difficulty breathing, new swallowing difficulty, rapid worsening of weakness, inability to walk, chest pain, or lightheadedness
GBS is typically a self-limited illness; most patients recover substantially but recovery may take months to years
Do NOT drive until strength and reflexes have recovered and neurology clears
Comply with physical therapy exercises as prescribed between sessions
Pain is normal in GBS and will be managed with medications; report if pain is inadequately controlled
Inform future healthcare providers about GBS history (vaccine considerations, anesthesia precautions)
Fall prevention: use assistive devices (walker, cane) as recommended; remove tripping hazards at home
Monitor for signs of blood clots: leg swelling, redness, chest pain, shortness of breath
Follow-up with neurology in 2-4 weeks after discharge; NCS/EMG may be repeated at 3-6 months

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Gradual return to activity as tolerated; avoid overexertion during recovery
Balanced nutrition for nerve recovery (adequate protein, B vitamins)
Mental health support (depression and anxiety common during recovery)
Flu vaccination: generally safe after GBS; discuss with neurologist (6 weeks post-onset minimum; risk-benefit individualized)
COVID-19 vaccination: discuss risk-benefit with neurologist; most experts recommend vaccination after recovery

differential.features: Sensory level, upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski), bladder involvement early, MRI spinal cord lesion
differential.tests: MRI spine (cord signal change); LP (pleocytosis more common); NCS/EMG (normal peripheral nerves)

differential.features: Fatigable weakness, ptosis, diplopia, intact reflexes, fluctuating symptoms, no sensory involvement
differential.tests: AChR antibodies, repetitive nerve stimulation (decremental), edrophonium test

differential.features: Descending paralysis (cranial nerves first), pupil involvement, GI prodrome, toxin exposure
differential.tests: Stool/serum botulinum toxin assay; NCS (incremental response at high-rate repetitive stimulation)

differential.features: Ascending paralysis similar to GBS; tick found on exam; rapid recovery after tick removal
differential.tests: Physical exam (search for tick, especially scalp); NCS may show reduced CMAPs; CSF normal

differential.features: Back pain, sensory level, upper motor neuron signs below level, bladder dysfunction
Abdominal pain, psychiatric symptoms, autonomic dysfunction, motor predominant neuropathy, dark urine
differential.tests: Urine ALA and PBG (elevated during attack)

differential.features: Asymmetric flaccid paralysis, fever, anterior horn cell pattern, CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: CSF (elevated WBC); viral PCR; MRI (anterior horn signal)

differential.features: Similar to GBS but progression >8 weeks, relapsing-remitting course, may respond to steroids
differential.tests: NCS/EMG (demyelinating); temporal course >8 weeks; steroid response

differential.features: ICU setting, prolonged ventilation, steroid/neuromuscular blocker exposure
differential.tests: NCS/EMG; CK (elevated in myopathy); clinical context

differential.features: Diffuse weakness, cardiac arrhythmia, normal reflexes or hyporeflexia
differential.tests: Serum potassium; ECG; rapid improvement with replacement

differential.features: Non-physiologic weakness pattern, Hoover sign, give-way weakness, psychiatric history
differential.tests: Normal NCS/EMG; normal LP; clinical exam

differential.features: Pharyngeal membrane, palatal weakness, sensorimotor neuropathy weeks after infection
Progressive, often sensory predominant; CSF pleocytosis distinguishes from GBS
differential.tests: HIV testing; CSF (WBC >50 suggests HIV, not classic GBS)

disposition.criteria: Mild GBS (ambulatory without assistance, Hughes 0-2), stable respiratory function (FVC >60% predicted), adequate pain control on oral medications, safe swallowing, reliable outpatient follow-up, family/caregiver support
Any GBS requiring treatment; unable to ambulate independently; FVC 20-30 mL/kg with no downward trend; mild bulbar symptoms; needs IVIG or PLEX

FVC <20 mL/kg or declining rapidly; NIF weaker than -30 cmH2O; intubated or imminent intubation; autonomic instability (BP lability, arrhythmia); severe bulbar weakness with aspiration risk; unable to protect airway

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for PLEX not available on-site; need for ICU with neurology expertise; rapidly progressive course
Significant motor deficits (unable to walk independently; Hughes 3-4); able to participate in 3h/day therapy; medically stable
Unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; requires ongoing nursing care; severe deconditioning
